title.narrative: Emergency agriculture assistance to drought-affected farmers in Kandahar, Faryab and Saripul

description.narrative: The severe and widespread drought throughout Afghanistan, significantly affected the Kandahar, Saripul and Faryab provinces In these provinces, the usual precipitation was much less than the average, thus resulting in very low soil moisture leading to poor germination and growing conditions for food crops and fodder vegetation reliant on rainfall as well as irrigation water. While enormous humanitarian needs remained unmet throughout the planting season up to after the harvest, it further increased the vulnerability, especially of smallholder farmers who have had their crops damaged or lost because of the drought. Key constraints contributing to further exposure and vulnerabilities for agriculture based livelihoods include limited or no access to inputs – certified wheat seeds and fertilizers limited government and aid agencies support to agriculture sector in these targeted areas, limited technical assistance to improve knowledge and skills on agricultural production and a reduction in small holder farmers’ post-harvest yields due to poor processing, handling and pest management. The ability of farming families to cope with this shock is significantly limited and has triggered negative coping mechanisms as families distress sell productive assets, including livestock, land, etc. in order to meet their basic needs, such as food. Farmers who have had an erratic wheat cultivation in the past season, did not have the purchase power to buy seeds to re-sow which highly impacts the food security of vulnerable families in the peak hunger season, which starts during winter. FAO will address the immediate humanitarian needs of drought-affected farming families in these three provinces and prevent loss of lives as a consequence of acute food insecurity, through the provision of essential agriculture inputs (certified wheat seed and quality fertilizers) , as per the FSAC recommended responses packages. FAO will assist drought-affected families to achieve enhanced resilience to future shocks through the introduction of improved wheat seeds that are more drought-resistant, coupled with training on improved agriculture practices. The interventions that FAO proposes will help preventing further migration of drought affected populations, reducing the likelihood of humanitarian services being burdened in high-concentration urban areas, widespread of acute food insecurity and malnutrition This proposed project is designed to be implemented in the provinces of Faryab, Kandahar and Saripul, which are FSAC’s high priority locations. Project activities are in line with revised HRP’s thematic priorities, that include targeting of drought affected vulnerable people.
